text: you could try an =importxml('<http://url.com/here|url.com/here>', '*') in google sheets
then copy it 50 times (max is 50 in a spreadsheet)
second parameter is your xpath markup (in this case * for all elements)
not actually sure if that would even work, but just thought I'd help get the creative juices goin...
Has anyone dealt with country code domains and regular domain on same portal (non-enterprise).
for instance..... <http://www.example.com|www.example.com> OR <http://www.example.com.uk|www.example.com.uk>
Or are these technically two separate domains that would need to both have their CNAMEs pointed to HubSpot (and set to use different content types in the domain settings)
Are you just trying to mass download the source files?
If so, SiteSucker for mac -- or this <https://www.httrack.com/page/2/>
this is awesome, thank you.
Yes they are both sperate..
seperate
The trick to URLs is ANY ANY ANY change regardless how small to the url is considered a new url.
so <http://www.example.com|www.example.com> is not the same as <http://example.com>
or <http://www.example.com.uk|www.example.com.uk>
you have to remember that technicaly anything that comes before the first period is considered a sub domain. even www.

I think we'll just be having the client set up a redirect from their purchased .<http://com.mx|com.mx> domain back to the appropriate translated page (with the /es/ affix automatically added from HubSpot)
